person.note: Hugh Auchincloss was a financier who married Emma Brewster Jennings, the daughter of an original founder of Standard Oil. He was educated at Yale and worked in the firm of Auchincloss Brothers of New York. He also managed private companies in mining, manufacturing, and transportation, while also having leadership positions in other organizations based in New York City.

Sir Edgar Bonham-Carter was the fifth son of Henry Bonham Carter. Sir Edgar held a long and esteemed legal career, taking roles like that of a British barrister, jurist, and legal administrator. He also held a 5 year term of office as judicial adviser in the semi military, semi-national administration set up in Mesopotamia, where he reestablished the judicial system of Sudan and Iraq. He was also a member of the Royal Society for Asian Affairs in London that stood to advance public knowledge of Asia. He was also the first Chairman of the Executive Committee of the British School of Archaeology located in Iraq.
Photographer; famous for his record of Tutankhamun's tomb. Worked with Theodore Davis and Howard Carter and the Metropolitan Museum's Egyptian Expedition.
The Earl was an artist and patron with a devotion mainly to landscapes. Egypt was one of his many travel destinations sought out both for art and the improvement of his health.

George Herbert, fifth earl of Carnarvon, was a British excavator and collector. He is best known for aiding Howard Carter with the opening of King Tutankhamun’s Tomb in 1922, although he did not live to see its clearance completed. Beyond the realm of excavations, Herbert also curated an expansive collection of Egyptian antiquities throughout his life.

A well acclaimed musician descended from a notable family. His stay in Egypt was the result of his largely unsettled lifestyle. While he and his wife visited Egypt they both performed for Emma B. Andrews and accompanied her to artistic productions.
19th century impressionist painter, travelled to Egypt in 1910.
Princess Louise Margaret of Prussia, later the Duchess of Connaught and Strathearn.
Duke and Duchess, Duke was also British Army officer and later Governor General of Canada. The Duchess later served as colonel-in-chief of 199th Canadian Infantry Batalion.
Princess Patricia of Connaught is the daughter of the Duke and Duchess of Connaught, born in 1886.

Lancelot Crane is best known for his artistic renderings and illustrations of art that covered Egyptian tombs, like the the tomb of Haremhab. He worked with Theodore Davis on many tombs and his artwork is prominently displayed at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City. He trained at the Royal College of Art.

Edmund Joseph Curley emigrated from Ireland to the USA about 1845. After the Civil War, Curley established the whiskey distillery E. J. Curley & Co. near Lexington, Kentucky. Between 1907 and 1912, Curley (using the honorific "Major") spent the summer months in Newport, Rhode Island where he entertained members of Newport society and likely made the acquaintance of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore M. Davis and EBA. In late 1912, he (and others including his friend the American banker Edward Tuck and his wife) visited EBA in Egypt (see diary entry for Saturday. Dec. 21, 1912).

Robert Henry Hobart Cust was an art historian. He attended the Eton School (1879-1882), and recieved his BA at the Trinity College Cambridge (1883-4) and MA at the Magdalen College Oxford (1886-7). He was a member of the Burlington Fine Arts Club and has published books on artists such as Botticelli (1906), Leonardo da Vinci (1907), and Benvenuto Cellini (1912).

Georges Emile Jules Daress was a French egyptologist who was employed by the Egyptian Museum in Cairo in 1887. He has published numerous works in relation to his excavations in the Valley of the Kings, Medinet Habu, and Luxor, to name a few.
Michael Zeno Diemer was a German painter who was well-known for his panoramic battle scenes and marine paintings. He attended the Academy of Fine Arts, Munich.

James Dixon was an English Egyptologist. He worked for the Egypt Exploration Fund in 1909-1911 as a draughtsman and copyist, reproducing inscriptions and other objects that were discovered. In 1912 He joined the Wellcome Sudan Expedition near Sennar as excavator and draughtsman. He also served as the Second-Lieutenant in the 6th Battalion of the Border Regiment until he died in the line of duty in 1915.

Gaspard Farrer was one of three sons of Sir William Farrer. His family has long ties to Farrer & Co., a law firm. He was discovered to be the founder of the National Fund (a British charity dedicated to paying off England's national debt), giving an anonymous donation of 500,000 pounds in 1928.
Matilda Travers married Walter Gay in 1889. She was the daughter of William Travers, a Wall Street investor and co-founder of the Saratoga Race Course.

Walter Gay was an American painter most well-known for his still lifes and interior scenes. In 1876, he moved to France with his wife where he studies under the French painter Leon Bonnat. Gay has recieved numerous awards in the US and in France including a gold medal in the Paris Salon (1885), Associate Academician in the National Academy of Design (1904), and Commander of the Legion of Honor (1927).
A prominent member of the British Diplomat corps and a Consul General in Egypt from 1907-1911.

The daughter of Charles Rudd, a financial 'magnate' and former business partner of Cecil Rhodes in South Africa. She is also known as the wife of Sir John Eldon Gorst, often referred to as 'Jack.' Lady Gorst accompanied Jack on many of his business trips to Egypt.
The daughter of Sir Jon Eldon Gorst, a prominent member of the British Diplomat corps and a Consul General in Egypt from 1907-1911. Miss Gorst accompanied her father on many of his trips to Egypt.

person.persName: Gosford, Lady Louisa Acheson, Countess of
Gosford, Lord Archibald Acheson, Earl of

person.note: A well known British diplomat and ambassador to Iraq (1974-1977), Iran (1979-1980) and NATO.

Winifred Ives was the daughter of Brayton Ives, the President of the Northern Pacific Railway. She was close friends with Grace Green Alexander and her daughter Eleanor Roosevelt (wife of Theodore Roosevelt Jr.).
Emma Brewster Jennings was married to Hugh Auchincloss, a businessman based in New York City. She was the daughter to Oliver Burr Jennings, an original founder of Standard Oil of Ohio.

Cyril Jones was the brother of the excavator, Ernest Harold Jones. He was a student at the Queen Elizabeth Grammar School between 1905 and 1909 and joined Harold on his return to Egypt. Due to Harold's worsening condition of tuberculosis, Cyril served as an assistant to Harold in his work in excavation, supervising, and letter writing. Later in Cyril's life, he became a farmer in South Africa.

Dikran Kelekian was a notable art collector and dealer with ties to many well-known individuals and artists such as Henry Walters, John D. Rockefeller Jr., Mary Cassatt, Pablo Picasso, and Henri Matisse. He studied ancient Near Eastern history at Robert College in Constantinople and went on to open numerous shops in cities such as New York, Paris, and London, exhibiting his collections in museums all over the world as well. In addition to his work as a dealer, he was appointed the Persian Council in New York and as the Commissioner for the Persian Pavilion at the World’s Columbia Exposition.
N. D. Kyticas has not been clearly identified, but it is known that they come from a well known family of antiquity dealers in Cairo, Egypt.

Lady Enid Layard was wife to her older cousin Austen Henry Layard, an archaeologist and diplomat. Her family and marriage status allowed her opportunities of travel and luxury. Per Henry’s will, her collection of early Italian art, portraits, and jewerly are now displayed in the British Museum and the National Gallery in London.

Gaston Maspero was an Egyptologist who taught Egyptian language at the College de France. After arcaheological work in Egypt he was appointed by the Egyptian government in 1881 as Director General of Antiquities, which was during Theodore Davis's period of excavation in the Valley of the Kings. He also co-founded the Egyptian Museum in Cairo, that has a vast collection Egyptian artifacts, in 1902.

person.persName: Miss Harrison and Miss Clarke (from the English dahabeah)

person.note: Employed by Theodore Davis as a connection to dealers and persons of importance.
Mohammed Mohassib was a popular Egyptian antiquities dealer in Luxor, and most of his collections were known for being incredibly valuable.
Business man and financier who was also an avid art collector and philanthropist.

Marguerite Naville married Edouard Naville in 1873. She accompanied him on a total of 14 trips to Egypt (1884-1914) where she managed excavation sites, cared for the workers, and recorded much of the findings made by Edouard and other Egyptologists at the time. A number of her photographs and drawings can be seen in her husband's publications.
Erskine E. Nicol was a landscape artist and the son of the renowned Scottish painter Erskine Nicol. His works, like his father's, were often exhibited at the Royal Academy of Arts in London.
Reverend Endicott Peabody was an Episcopal priest and educator who founded the Groton School for Boys and Brooks School.

person.persName: Ponsonby, Lieut, the, Hon, M, B
Raineria, Felicitas, Desideria, Henriette, Christina, Maria, Queen

person.note: Coming from a long line of Rathbones, Elena Rathbone was the daughter of William Gair Rathbone VII and Blanche Luling. She was a supporter of District Nursing, and she served several positions until becoming vice-president in 1956 for the Queen's Institute for District Nursing.

Son to William Rathbone VI and Lucretia Rathbone, and father to Elena Rathbone, William Gair Rathbone VII worked within his family business, the Rathbone Brothers. Continuing his father's legacy, he also served as Honorary Secretary of the Queen Victoria's Jubilee Institute for Nurses.
Breifly mentioned, attended lunch with Emma B. Andrews

Reverend Archibald Sayce was a professor of Assyriology at Queen's College in Oxford. His work, which involved the writing of scholarly reviews and articles on Near Eastern civilizations, took him to locations all over the world in addition to Egypt.
Judicial Advisor to the Khedive of Egypt
Wife of Salah, noted to have a child and live somewhat lavishly.
Professor Tarbell's reasons for being in Egypt are not yet known. However, he spent several days with Emma B. Andrews, dining with them after delivering a letter.
Entombed in KV 14 before being moved to KV 13. Cartouches were found elsewhere and their discovery was noted in volume 15. The last ruler of the New Kingdom, succeeding her husband Seti II.
English actress whose work was enjoyed by Emma B. Andrews, who attended her performance in The Dead Heart: A Story of the French Revolution in London.

Known for expanding the borders and influence of the Egyptian New Kingdom to their gratest extent. He is referenced within the diaries with relation to architecture which is admired by Emma B. Andrews - The Karnak Temple Complex in particular is noted.
Captain Trefusis was the Colonel of the 2nd Battalion in the Scots Guards and was the son of the 19th Baron Clinton, Charles Trefusis.

Lina Post Webster was the wife of Hamilton Fish Webster. After moving to Newport with her husband, she became very involved in the community, becoming the first woman to be elected to the Representative Council in Newport (1933) and serving as the president of the Newport County Women's Democratic Club (1934).

Arthur Weigall became an Egyptologist after studying the subject for several years before working under Flinders Petrie and Friedrich Wilhelm von Bissing. At 25, he assumed the position as Inspector of Antiquities for Upper Egypt and wrote several books and biographies about the tombs that he helped recover. Weigall eventually became a set-dsigner in London as well as a journalist for Daily Mail, where he covered the opening of Tutankhamun's tomb.
Enjoyed tea with Emma and Theodore. Perhaps traveled with the Bends to Ravenna and Venice.

Thomas Whittemore is best known for founding the Byzantine Institute in 1930 and initiating the conservation project at Hagia Sophia in Istanbul, Turkey in 1931. He also worked with Edouard Naville as the American representative for the British-run Egypt Exploration Society. With a history in academia, he also held titles as a docent, assistant professor and was a special collaborator of the U.S. Bureau of Education.
Charles Whymper was a painter and engraver who was popular for book illustrations on hunting and travelling.

Herbert Eustis Winlock was an American egyptologist for the MET. After he graduated from Harvard, he became involved in various expeditions with the MET including the discovery of the tomb of Tutankhamun by Howard Carter. He has also published numerous works, his most well-known being Tutankhamun's Funeral (1941).

settingDesc.listPlace: Antique shop in Venice likely owned by Dino Barozzinot the actor but a small city in DCPrivate garden in VeniceBell tower on St Mark's Basilica in Venice
